content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Turns out rule 4 was actually relevant after all! 

The testcases are very well thought, and the puzzle was engaging enough to make me overcome my chronic hate of the X < Y case. This is easily the codingame puzzle that has (consensually) stolen the most time of mine :D

A very satisfying experience.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Outstanding puzzle! Over 8 months of work has gone into this puzzle since the original submission and it shows. The test cases are incredibly thorough. The design of the puzzle requires solutions to have a little bit of optimization, a little bit of combinatorics and a little bit of algorithmic complexity. None of those concepts alone are crazy tough, but the way this puzzle puts them all together creates a really nice hard level, yet doable, puzzle.

One suggestion - if it were me, I would eliminate rule 4, which doesn't seem critical to me, but definitely provides a solid hint for the optimization part of the puzzle. This is not a deal-breaker for me, just a thought.

It's back in Ready! Main differences with the earlier 'Ready' contribution:
- case 11 added to check for optimization;
- cases 15-21 added for a variety of newly discovered edge cases (credits to @Timinator for helping me get to the bottom of this)
- case 22 (final case) altered to incorporate some of the edge mechanisms.

This revised contribution is a bit more difficult than the earlier version. I am curious what the opinion is on difficulty level - keep it at Medium or switch it to Hard? Thanks in advance for your thoughts, CG community!
I have drawn the puzzle back in WIP due to the discovery of some nice additional edge cases. I'll work those out properly and add them before putting this contribution back to Ready.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle, the statement is long but it's clear.
Lots of tests/validators that seems to cover all the edge cases.
Resubmitted after making the changes suggested by Timinator (swapped test- and validator for cases 8 and 12).

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Hey, it's my first time commenting a puzzle but this problem statement is well-crafted and engaging. The concept of simulating supermarket advertisements and calculating the final price is a very good way to adds a practical touch to the problem.  The only minor suggestion  I have is that I found the problem a little bit hard that way and the Medium difficulty is maybe a little bit low, or maybe I'm just a noob :) Overall, a great exercise that encourages logical thinking and coding skills!
This is a surprisingly interesting puzzle. Easy if you are organized and read before you start writing code. Very original, and a good way to learn about edge case testing. ðŸ‘

Maybe it's just me but I can't make any sense of the case X < Y to save my life.

Could you explain how you get -80 in test 7?

Resubmitted with some changes:
- Added three test/validators, and reordered the cases, for a better build-up of situations across different axes (one or more, good or bad, items applying or not, non-mixed or mixed)
- Changed the final test&validator (Action Action!) slightly to let the outcome not be too negative.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

I am almost ready to approve. The author and I have talked about a couple of very minor narrative ideas that I'll wait for.

This is a puzzle that grew on me over time. It is deceptively challenging in a real world sort of way. All the information I needed to solve it was right in the problem statement, but I kept drifting off track into my own thoughts of how "things should be".

I also struggled to build a good abstract model of the problem in my code, again because, in my mind, I understood the requirements better than the author. (I hear this is sometimes still an issue for software developers.)

Very nice puzzle. I would not mind if this puzzle requires another 30 days for full approval. I ran across some nice edge case testing in the end that I'd be glad to explore a bit further.

Validator 10 has an interesting edge case that I don't believe shows up anywhere else. Earlier this morning, I was passing all test cases and all validators except Validator 10. I've found that passing all test cases, but still failing a validator is one of the most frustrating experiences on CG, so I suggest we see if you can address the edge case in an earlier test case.

I believe the edge case happens in a situation like this: 3 apples for the price of 2 and you have 10 apples in your cart with different prices. I think my error was in identifying which apple to leave out of the applied advertisement.

I'll send you a PM with my earlier code that can pass all test cases, but fails validator 10.

Resubmitted, since it suddenly got 10 upvotes just before the 30 days of moderation passed.

Thank you very much in advance if you take the time to validate this contribution :-) !

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Great problem statement! Clear instructions, well-defined input/output formats, and concise rules and constraints. This task combines string parsing, data manipulation, and decision-making logic for an interesting challenge. It's a valuable opportunity to learn and apply skills in loops, strings, arrays, and permutations. Thanks for creating it!

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Please change "diary" to "dairy" in test cases.

I'm working through a solution. As I'm sure you know, your extensive test cases and edge testing is getting me every time.

All seafood: 2 for the price of 3

Why would I pay the price of 3 when I'm only getting 2 pieces of seafood? I don't understand the scenario where Y > X.

I think I would go get my shrimp and take them to the car. Then come back in and grab my salmon. That way, I never "qualify" for this bad deal, right?

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

2
All milk: 4 for the price of 3
All france: 2 for the price of 1
6
milk diary holland 3
milk diary holland 1
milk diary france 1
milk diary france 1
cheese diary france 2
cheese diary france 2

Your solution gives:
3.00
7.00

but it should be:
5.00
5.00

Unless I misunderstood this:

For example, 10 items qualify for the advertisement A: 3 for 2, and of those 10, 5 also quality for advertisement B: 4 for 1. If advertisements are considered in order A -> B, then first A will be applied as much as possible (3 * 3 for 2), leaving only 1 item for advertisement B. If instead the order of B -> A is considered, then first B will be applied (2 * 4 for 1), leaving only 2 items for A.)

2
All milk: 2 for the price of 1
All france: 2 for the price of 1
4
milk diary holland 1
milk diary france 4
milk diary holland 3
cheese diary france 2

Your solution gives:
2.00
8.00

but it should be:
3.00
7.00

no?

Difficulty
* Your puzzle seems to be more complex than:
https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/the-voucher

So I think it is appropriate to classify it to at least Medium.

Input section
* You may change "Line na+1" to "Next line".

Output section
* Line 1: Please change "decimals" to "decimal places".

* Line 2: Please change "two decimals" to "with two decimal places".

Constraints section
* Please fix the third constraint.

* Last constraint: Please change "<" to "<=" for consistency with some of the cases.

Goal section
* Please change "decimals" to "decimal places".

* Please specify how rounding is done - round to 2 decimal places or truncate to 2 decimal places.

* Suggest to change "There will never be mixture of product, group or brand names" to "All names (product, group and brand names) are unique".

* Please add "." after "benefit of the customer".

* Please change "test-" to "tests", and ";" to ".".

* Please change "a next" to "the next".

* I'd like the last point to be clarified: do you mean:
"In case of multiple advertisements, when calculating which application results in the highest discount,..."?
I mean I may apply A then B to calculate discount 1, and then apply B then A to calculate discount 2, and compare discount 1 and discount 2 to decide which application should be used. Is that the intended approach? The current wording gives me an impression that I don't have to consider applying B then A.

* "-- If of X items, Y need to be paid, and X>Y, the highest prices are waived. (If, by some mistake, X<Y, the lowest prices are added)"
Erm... initially I thought the case of X<Y should be removed because it didn't make sense. And then I think, hey we're just the IT guys, we don't make the business decisions for management, so...
Suggest to change "by some mistake" to "to discourage customers from bulk purchasing limited-stock items", and remove the brackets. Also suggest to add an example e.g. "All vegetables: 3 for the price of 5" here, because initially I had no idea what this point referred to.

Thanks.

Looking forward to hear comments.

One remark on the difficulty: I am not sure. I started with 'Easy', which I think is the case with all situations in which there are not multiple advertisements applicable for one item. However, I struggled myself with the solution for the cases in which there are multiple advertisements applicable for the same items (cases 7 and 10), and have for that reason now set it at 'Medium'.

Cool! I've updated the puzzle according to most of your suggestions. Some remarks:
- I do not see the need for specifying rounding. There will never be any multiplication or division, only the removal(or addition) of prices. So, for example, out of 3.00, 2.00, 4.50, 2.00 and 2.50, the 4.50 is waived due to 2 for 1 on deodorant. So, result is some combination of adding all prices and subtracting the discount -- and finally giving that as output with two decimal places; rounding is never an issue in my opinion.
- I have tried to clarify the last point by specifying that the other order is also possible, and that the order, which leads to the best result for the customer, needs to be used. Indeed, like you state it (first calculate A-B then B-A and compare) is the intended approach. Mainly, with this point I want to avoid the complexity of 'a bit of A and a bit of B'; that would lead to much more possible discount variations (and I did not know how to program the solution for that :-)).
- The X<Y case I particularly like. I want to leave it in the middle whether it is to discourage customers, or to trick customers, or whether it is a genuine mistake. I like the point where an IT guy can simply deliver what is requested, but that possibly the request is stupid. I did kind of want to keep it a secret (small twist to run into when working on cases 8 and 9), but I do on the other hand agree that text in a statement should be clear --> for the X<Y I have added an example in the statement).

Absolutely correct. Thanks to your case I discovered a mistake in my solution; I meant to sort the items based on itemprices (to, based on that, take away the highest and lowest priced items according to an applied advertisement), but I had instead simply sorted based on item number. I have corrected that now, and your holland france case with the new solution indeed gives 3.00 7.00.

Thanks!

By the way, All france 2 for the price of 1, sounds like a good deal.

Right again, another mistake in my solution code. The updated solution does indeed give 5.00/5.00. Amazingly, this updated solution lead to no difference for all other tests&validators, so you managed to find an additional relevant case, which I added. At the moment I am not sharp enough to realize exactly what is different about this one.

(The mistake in my code was that I only marked X items as used, while that should be X * the times the advertisement could be applied. I guess there was not yet a test/validator situation in which there were items qualifying for multiple advertisements AND one of those adds could be applied multiple times AND that still would be the worse option - hm maybe I do realize what the difference is after all)

One question: you nicely test your own scenarios - do you do that simply by temporarily adding a test/validator pair, or is there some smarter way to test other scenarios?

No interest in diaries for a good deal?
Thanks, I'll change it.

And thanks for working through the cases! I hope you run into edge cases instead of mistakes from my side.

Thanks for the positive feedback! Until shortly it did not gather upvotes, but yesterday suddenly 10 were added, so I decided to resubmit the contribution after all. Hopefully within the coming 30 days there are three people as enthusiastic as you, and willing to spend their time on approving this contribution :-).

Thanks a lot for diving in! As a quick fix I have switched validator and test 10, because indeed you should not run into a validator when succeeding all tests. I hope to find the time to check the discrepancy in order to come with a better solution.

Thanks for the nice feedback. I have also no problem with adding another round of 30 days; if I can find the time I might try to add some cases that test the edges in more detail, based on your input.

That has everything to do with rule 5, and then specifically 'if X smaller than y, the lowest price is added'.

2 for the price of 6, with six items all qualifying, means that it can be applied 3 times (3 times 2 products available). So, three times a pair needs to be made of which the lowest price is added. The case best for the customer is pairs of 5/30, 5/30 and 10/10. For the 5/30 pair, 5 is added 4 times, to get 2 for the price of 6 (items 5 and 30 for the price of 5,5,5,5,5,30). In other words, total price becomes (5*5+30)+(5*5+30)+(10*5+10) = 170. The price without this ad would be 5+5+10+10+30+30=90, so the 'discount' is -80.
Thanks! :-)

Thanks for the positive feedback (and apologies for the delayed reply). Concerning the difficulty: I also found it difficult to solve this puzzle while creating it, but I am hesitant on whether it is a 'difficult Medium' or truly a 'Hard' puzzle. I have had quite some difficulty with other Medium puzzles as well. And, I somehow feel that the difficulty of this puzzle is more in the correct implementation rather than the actual coding (i.e. the coding needed to solve this is not 'Hard' - also not 'Easy', therefore 'Medium' :-) ). So, for now I keep it on 'Medium', but I am open to change if others also think so.

I added two dedicated edge cases: one with Y=0 (case 14), and one where first one advertisement and then another can be applied (case 15). Also updated the constraints section to clarify that X cannot be 0.
It did not cover all edge cases after all; I will send you a PM for more info.

Cases 15-22 are added today in relation to the discovered additional edge cases. I will change these cases (validators are at the moment simply copy of tests) and their names later on, but they already reflect the added dimensions to this puzzle.
I would say it definitely deserve the "Hard" classification now, still working on updating my previous solution.

Thanks a lot for the positive feedback, and for your time and effort in working through the cases with me.

I fully agree that rule 4 ('There can be adverts without items and items without adverts') is redundant. Running into an error because of an advertisement that is not used or an item that is not part of an advertisement will be one of the easy errors to solve for this contribution. I have removed this rule, thanks.
Thank you very much for your time; the way you ran into edge cases forced me to improve my understanding of my own contribution multiple times, and update cases accordingly.

While I was trying to solve this puzzle after its approval, the author and I found three pairs of duplicate cases (6, 7 and 12). They've now been fixed.

I do think you've done a decent job in checking this puzzle before approval. And I understand this is a complex puzzle, so you might have overlooked the issue because of that. So, this is just a gentle reminder to you to check for duplicate cases, among other things, before approving contributions in the future.

Thank you for your understanding.
Do you mean that the validator was the same as the corresponding test? If so I have to admit that I didn't check that. I'll try to pay more attention next time.

Well it's not that you spent barely any time on validating this one.

Indeed, I had accidentally left in some identical test/validators. At some point I made them all identical, because a certain person had a knack for writing code that passed tests but failed validators.

While I was trying to solve this puzzle after its approval, the author and I found three pairs of duplicate cases (6, 7 and 12). They've now been fixed.

I do think you've done a decent job in checking this puzzle before approval. And I understand this is a complex puzzle, so you might have overlooked the issue because of that. So, this is just a gentle reminder to you to check for duplicate cases, among other things, before approving contributions in the future.

Thank you for your understanding.
Thanks for the feedback, I will set it to 'Hard'.
I just passed 1 to 45 and failed on 46. I'll have to investigate why, but I just want to notate a case of passing all tests, but failing a validator.
Thanks for sharing. Did you find a higher or lower discount than the given solution for 46?
Lower. I think my answer is definitely wrong, but I haven't figured out why yet.

I fixed my problem and I'm now passing all 46.

45 and 46 both have an x <  y advert, but only in 46 does the x < y advert also have overlap with another advert. In my mind, this makes 45 somewhat easier than 46.

For your information: I have changed the contribution after your approval (added edge cases force to select the best items not only for a current advertisement, but also taking into account which advertisements come after the current one). I am glad with your earlier approval, but I suspect that your solution code for that approval does not work for the revised contribution.

It took me longer than I had anticipated but I have finally solved the updated version.
You and Timinator did a great job with all the tests/validators :D
Awesome, thanks for taking the time!

While I was trying to solve this puzzle after its approval, the author and I found three pairs of duplicate cases (6, 7 and 12). They've now been fixed.

I do think you've done a decent job in checking this puzzle before approval. And I understand this is a complex puzzle, so you might have overlooked the issue because of that. So, this is just a gentle reminder to you to check for duplicate cases, among other things, before approving contributions in the future.

Thank you for your understanding.
Hi Skrii, for your information, I have changed the difficulty level to Hard after all (but, it did also become a bit harder, after adding couple of new situations).

Thanks, now I am in an awkward situation where I pass every test except the last one, while failing some validators (Good for business 1: validator, Mixed advertisements 2: validator, Action Action! Validator).

I assume that I have a couple of bugs related to x < y and multiple advertisements but I wouldn't know if I hadn't access to the validators, so maybe more similar tests pairs could be added?

I could try to look for the issue myself to suggest you a relevant example but I'm mentally done for today.

I do have an idea of where it may come from, but anyway it may be interesting to look again at the tests before I go on and fix the code. 

I will send you the code by PM, not the most readable piece of python though, but you can verify what I claim about passing tests but not validators.
Could I take a look at your code also? I'm passing all tests and all validators now and I'm having a hard time figuring out ways to change my code to pass some things but not all.

First of all, I love the complexity of how the products and the advertisements interact on this puzzle. However, I do believe we have to do everything possible to avoid situations where test cases can be passed while validators still fail. I'm not sure this is a perfect solution, but here are my thoughts.

@Rafarafa has some code that does the following:

Pass "8 Good for business 1"
Fail "Good for business 1: validator"

Pass: "12 Mixed advertisements 2"
Fail: "Mixed advertisements 2: validator"

I think the puzzle might benefit from swapping the test case and the validator in both of these situations. For each, I think the validator has slightly more complexity than the test case and that leaves the door open for passing the test case while failing the validator.

Re: Good for Business

The test case is 2 for the price of 4 with 8 qualifying products. Even the eight qualifying products can be broken into two groups of 4 by brand/price.  Nice symmetry. Everything is a power of 2. I feel like this symmetry allowed the bug to slide through.

The validator is 3 for the price of 5 with 9 qualifying products which can be broken into a group of 4 and a group of 5 based on brand/price. I wish I knew how to articulate it better, but I believe this less symmetrical product layout catches bugs not caught in the test case.

Re: Mixed Advertisements 2

Let's look at the 4 advertisements for the test case:
4 snacks for the price of 3 --> 5 products qualify
3 nuts for the price of 2 --> 3 products qualify
2 icecream for the price of 1 -->  2 products qualify
10 desserts for the price of 6 --> 10 products qualify

In 3 of the 4 advertisements, the number of qualifying products is conveniently exactly what the advertisement calls for. Only one advertisement will leave some product unaccounted for after the advertisement is applied.

Compare that to the validator:
4 nuut for the price of 3 --> 4 products qualify
3 cheeseplatter for the price of 1 --> 4 products qualify
3 snacks for the price of 2 --> 5 products qualify
10 desserts for the price of 6 -->  13 products qualify

In 3 of the 4 validator advertisements, leftover product must be accounted for after the advertisement is applied. I believe this added complexity might be what catches bugs the test case did not.

That's the best I can come up with. I hope it helps!
Apologies for my absence, I'm a couple of weeks without laptop and I don't feel comfortable doing CG editing on my phone. As soon as I'm back, I'll pick this up again.

Ok, I followed the suggestions from Timinator and swapped test- and validator for case 8 and 12. Not the most elegant solution; I prefer to have test- and validator cases in balance. However, the interaction between adverts and items on their three parameters results in a complexity that I cannot easily see through - I therefore have difficulty in understanding what exactly the edge case is here (and can therefore not replicate it or explain it). I guess Timinator is onto something (difference between having an exact number of items fitting versus a not exact number) - but I do not know where to look for in Rafarafa's code to explain why this difference matters.

I've just had a fresh look at the statement (not the cases).

Goal section
* Rule 3: Suggest to add "single words" after "unique".

Stub generator
* Please change "word(6)" to "float".

Thanks.
(Just in case you missed my latest commentâ€¦)
Whoops missed these replies, thanks for alerting me. I have just implemented your comments, thanks!
"7 A bad textile deal" test is the same as "A bad textile deal validator" validator. Please fix the case(s). Thanks.
Done - actually the same was the case for 6 test & validator - I made small changes to both validators. Thanks!

While I'm trying to solve your puzzle, I've found more duplicate cases :( Test 12 and Validator 12 are the same. I would suggest you to add "duplicate checking" to your checklist for future contributions. Thanks.

Thanks again and apologies. As thanks for your sharpness you can get a special discount at Validator 12 - all Arial5D 4 for the price of only 1!

And I do need to add that to my checklist indeed; especially with this contribution I (and others) ran into unexpected edge cases, so at some point I did not dare to deviate my validator cases too much from my test cases, in fear of introducing an unmeant difference between test and validator - during WIP I simply switched to identical test and validators. But that means that at the Ready contribution I must more carefully check whether they are at all different. NB: currently at my Rummikub contribution most tests/validators are identical still, because also for that one I am not yet beyond edge case discovery. I'll be sure however to make them all different before turning it into Ready.

Thank you very much for your reply and the Arial5D :D

I'll also write reminders to the approvers here shortly.
